Cost–output diagram with four curves labelled I, II, III and IV; one of them is the firm's marginal cost curve for Question 10.
Price–quantity diagram for Question 25 showing a horizontal supply curve P1S at price P1.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: Which of the following items is NOT included in measuring national income by the income approach?

options.text: Wages and salaries of public servants
Income earned by self‑employed persons such as lawyers

questions.explanation: The income approach sums factor incomes—wages, interest, rent and profit—earned from current production. Student grants and scholarships are transfer payments, not payments for productive services, so they are excluded from national income.

questions.question: A downward‑sloping demand curve intersects a fixed supply curve. A shift of this demand curve to the right implies that

options.text: both price and quantity will increase

questions.explanation: A fixed supply curve is vertical: quantity supplied is fixed. When demand increases (shifts right), equilibrium occurs at the same quantity but a higher price. Thus only price rises while quantity remains unchanged.

questions.question: Which of the following items is NOT an argument for locating industries in rural areas?

options.text: Rural areas supply agricultural raw materials
The pace of development will be quickened in rural areas
Employment will be provided for rural inhabitants
Capital is easily available in rural areas
Suitable humid climate is sometimes found in rural areas

questions.explanation: Rural locations are attractive because of raw materials, employment, regional development, and sometimes favourable climate. Capital, however, is usually harder—not easier—to obtain in rural areas, so D is not a valid argument.

questions.question: In the diagram (Econ1983_Fig1), D₁D₁ and D₂D₂ are demand curves while S₀S₀ and S₂S₂ are supply curves for a manufactured good. What happens when government subsidizes producers in order to boost output?

options.text: The supply curve will shift from S₀S₀ to S₂S₂
The supply curve will shift from S₀S₀ to S₁S₁
The supply curve will shift from S₂S₂ to S₁S₁
The supply curve will shift from S₁S₁ to S₀S₀
The demand curve will shift from D₁D₁ to D₂D₂

questions.explanation: A subsidy lowers firms’ costs so that at each price they are willing to supply more. Graphically, the supply curve shifts rightward from the original S₀S₀ to S₂S₂. A subsidy affects supply, not demand, so E is wrong, and the direction of shift is to the right, not left (ruling out C and D).

questions.question: The natural growth rate of a population is the

options.text: sum of the birth rate and the death rate
sum of the birth rate and the net migration rate
birth rate minus the death rate
birth rate divided by the net migration rate
death rate minus the net migration rate

questions.explanation: Natural population increase excludes migration and is computed as **birth rate − death rate**. Options involving migration (B, D, E) do not represent the natural growth rate.

questions.question: Which of the following sets fully represents factors of production?
questions.explanation: The four classical factors of production are **land, labour, capital, and enterprise (entrepreneurship)**. Other options either omit a factor or include institutions and outcomes (money, market, middlemen, technology) rather than basic inputs.

questions.question:
A production‑possibility table is given as follows:

Alternative:      P   Q   R   S   T
Units of shelter: 5   4   3   2   0
Units of food:    0   9   12  15  18

Based on the above table, the real cost of a unit of food when alternative R is selected is

options.text: one‑third of a unit of shelter

questions.explanation: Moving from Q to R, food increases from 9 to 12 (∆food = +3) while shelter falls from 4 to 3 (∆shelter = −1). Thus 1 unit of shelter forgone yields 3 units of food. The opportunity cost of **one unit of food** is 1⁄3 unit of shelter.

questions.question: The concept of economic efficiency primarily refers to

options.text: obtaining the maximum output from available resources at the lowest possible cost
equity in the distribution of the nation's wealth
the dilemma of limited wants and unlimited resources

questions.explanation: Economic efficiency is achieved when a given set of resources yields **maximum possible output at minimum cost**. Option D mentions absence of waste but omits the output‑maximisation idea; A captures both.

questions.question: If successive units of labour are added to a piece of land while capital and technology remain constant, a point will be reached when each additional unit of labour adds less to output than the previous one. This illustrates

options.text: the law of diminishing marginal utility

questions.explanation: With one variable factor (labour) and other factors fixed, the falling marginal product of labour is an example of the **law of diminishing returns**. Marginal utility (B) relates to consumer satisfaction, not production.

questions.question: In perfect competition a firm's price is equal to its marginal revenue, which is again equal to average revenue. The firm maximizes profit when its marginal cost (MC) is equal to price. In the diagram (Econ1983_Fig2), which of the curves most likely represents the firm's marginal cost (MC)?
questions.explanation: The MC curve is typically **U‑shaped**: falling at low output (due to increasing returns) and rising at higher output (due to diminishing returns). In the given diagram, Curve III has that shape and intersects the average cost curve at its minimum, so it best represents MC.

questions.question: A Nigerian household's demand curve for semovita is downward sloping because

options.text: the demand for semovita is high
the local markets are flooded with semovita
every household can afford to buy semovita
higher prices attract lower quantities while lower prices attract larger quantities

questions.explanation: A downward‑sloping demand curve reflects the **law of demand**: as price rises, quantity demanded falls, and vice versa. Option E states this inversely proportional relationship explicitly.

questions.question:
The table below shows the market schedule for semovita.

PRICE per 5 kg bag (₦) | QUANTITY DEMANDED (bags) | QUANTITY SUPPLIED (bags)
300                      | 15,000                   | 1,500
400                      | 13,000                   | 3,000
500                      | 10,000                   | 6,000
600                      | 7,000                    | 7,000
700                      | 5,000                    | 9,000
800                      | 4,000                    | 12,000
900                      | 2,000                    | 14,000

What is the market equilibrium price?
questions.explanation: Equilibrium occurs where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied. From the table this happens at **₦600**, where both demand and supply are 7,000 bags. Hence ₦600 is the equilibrium price.

questions.question: A marginal cost curve intersects the average cost curve

options.text: from above at its lowest point
from below before the lowest point
from below at its lowest point
from below after the lowest point

questions.explanation: When MC is below AC, it pulls AC down; when MC is above AC, it pulls AC up. Therefore MC crosses AC exactly at AC's **minimum point**, coming from below. So it intersects from below at the lowest point.

questions.question: Palm‑oil industry is located in Bendel State because the state

options.text: imports raw material for the palm‑oil industry
has soil unsuitable for other crops
government does not engage in land use for crops
land is suitable only for oil

questions.explanation: Agro‑based industries tend to locate close to their **raw materials** to reduce transport costs. Bendel is a palm‑tree growing area, providing the fruit used in palm‑oil production.

questions.question: The term "wage‑price spiral" refers to a situation in which

options.text: demand‑pull and cost‑push inflation pull each other in different directions
demand‑pull and cost‑push inflation intensify each other
both of them bring about a reduction in the price level
wages and prices are rising at a proportional rate
demand‑pull and cost‑push inflation increase employment

questions.explanation: In a wage‑price spiral, higher wages raise firms' costs, pushing prices up; higher prices then lead workers to demand higher wages. Wages and prices **chase each other upwards**, rising roughly in step, which is captured by option D.

questions.question: In an inflationary period, which of the following statements is NOT true?

options.text: The purchasing power of money diminishes
More money units are chasing a limited quantity of goods
Aggregate real demand exceeds aggregate real supply

questions.explanation: In reality, wages typically **lag behind** rising prices, so workers' real incomes fall. All the other options (B–E) are consistent with inflationary conditions. Hence A is the statement that is not generally true.

questions.question: Retailers in an economy perform the function of
questions.explanation: Retailers buy goods in bulk from wholesalers and **distribute** them in small quantities to final consumers. While this involves exchange, the primary economic function is distribution from producer to consumer.

questions.question: In a sole proprietorship the decisions are made by the
questions.explanation: A sole proprietorship has a single owner who both supplies capital and **takes all decisions**. There is no separate board or group of shareholders.

questions.question: Which of the following enterprises does NOT pursue the sole objective of profit maximization?
questions.explanation: NEPA is a public utility whose main goal is to provide electricity as a **social service**, not simply to maximise profit. The other organisations are commercial firms whose core objective is profit.

questions.question: Public expenditure creates expansionary effects in the economy when it is

options.text: completely financed out of tax receipts

questions.explanation: Expenditure on **capital projects** (roads, schools, power) raises aggregate demand now and increases productive capacity later. That is expansionary. Spending on imports (C) leaks abroad; the financing source (D, E) does not by itself determine whether the effect is expansionary.

questions.question: The maintenance of general economic stability in a federal country necessarily relies heavily on

options.text: coordinated federal, state and local fiscal policies
tax and revenue policies of state governments
federal grants to state and local governments

questions.explanation: In a federal system, different tiers of government share taxing and spending powers. For macroeconomic **stabilisation** (controlling inflation and unemployment), fiscal policies at all levels must be **coordinated**, not pursued independently.

questions.question: The supply of loanable funds in the economy is most significantly influenced by
questions.explanation: Commercial banks are the **main mobilisers of deposits and savings**, which they lend out as credit. While other institutions also lend, commercial banks dominate the supply of short‑term loanable funds.

questions.question: Which of the following are direct taxes?
questions.explanation: Direct taxes are levied on **income or wealth** and are borne by the taxpayer (e.g. personal income tax, company tax). Sales, excise and tariff duties are indirect taxes on goods and services.

questions.question: Division of labour has many advantages. Notwithstanding, it is greatly limited by
questions.explanation: Adam Smith pointed out that division of labour is limited by the **extent of the market**: specialisation makes sense only if the market is large enough to absorb the output. Other problems (monotony, boredom, etc.) are drawbacks but not the fundamental limit.

questions.question: In the diagram (Econ1983_Fig3), P₁S is a supply curve for a manufactured good. It shows that

options.text: when price is P₁, quantity supplied is infinitely elastic
the higher the price, the greater the quantity supplied
the higher the price, the lower the quantity supplied
when price is zero, quantity supplied becomes infinite
when price is infinite, quantity supplied becomes zero

questions.explanation: A horizontal supply curve at price P₁ means producers are willing to supply **any quantity at price P₁**, but none at prices below it. This describes a perfectly elastic supply (infinite elasticity) at that price.

questions.question: In the event of a limited liability company going into liquidation each

options.text: shareholder may lose at most the amount he has invested
shareholder loses everything including his house
shareholder will lose the amount he has invested plus a proportion of his bank account

questions.explanation: In a **limited liability** company, the maximum loss a shareholder can suffer is the amount invested in shares. Personal assets are protected; thus A is correct and C, D, E are wrong.

questions.question: A greater burden of taxes on essential goods is borne by the

options.text: people falling between the middle and higher‑income groups

questions.explanation: Demand for essential goods is highly **inelastic**. When such goods are taxed, all consumers pay more, but the poor feel the burden most because the tax takes a larger share of their income. Hence the lower‑income group bears a heavier relative burden.

questions.question: The comparative cost doctrine of international trade means specialization in production

options.text: on the basis of the availability of labour

questions.explanation: According to Ricardo’s comparative cost doctrine, countries gain by specializing in goods they can produce at **lower opportunity cost** (comparative advantage), not necessarily lowest absolute cost.

questions.question: The meaning of "dumping" is selling goods in a foreign market

options.text: at a price lower than that received in the home market
at a price higher than that received in the home market
at a price equal to the cost price in the home market
in order to encourage indigenous producers
at a price equal to the selling price in the home market

questions.explanation: "Dumping" is the practice of selling exports at a **lower price abroad** than at home, often below cost, to gain foreign market share. So A is correct.

questions.question: Disequilibrium in the balance of payments means

options.text: imports of the country exceeding its exports
an overall deficit or surplus in the current and capital accounts of the balance of payments
capital flowing out of the country exceeds the capital flowing into the country
a deficit in the trade balance only
exports and imports equal the cost of imports

questions.explanation: The balance of payments is in disequilibrium when there is an **overall surplus or deficit** on the current and capital accounts combined. A and D refer only to trade; C refers only to capital movements.

questions.question: Petroleum "glut" in international trade means

options.text: a higher petroleum price offered by the buyer
a higher petroleum price demanded by the seller
higher prices for the consumption of petroleum

questions.explanation: A "glut" is a situation of **excess supply** over demand, causing downward pressure on prices. So a petroleum glut means an oversupply of petroleum.

questions.question: International trade is necessary because

options.text: no country can live in economic isolation
different countries are differently endowed with natural and man‑made resources
some countries have comparative cost advantage in the production of particular commodities
the world demand for and supply of various commodities is expanding very fast
countries want to build up their foreign exchange reserves

questions.explanation: The fundamental reason for trade is **differences in resource endowment**: countries lack some resources but have others in abundance. Comparative advantage (C) is a consequence of these differences but B states the more basic reason.

questions.question: Mono‑product economies are those that

options.text: live from the export of raw products

questions.explanation: A mono‑product economy depends heavily on **one main commodity** (e.g. oil in Nigeria, cocoa in Ghana) for export earnings and government revenue.

questions.question: The quickest way of achieving an economic union on a regional basis is to remove all
questions.explanation: Economic unions are built by gradually reducing **trade barriers** (tariffs, quotas, etc.) among member countries. Removing trade restrictions is the key economic step; currency, legal, or political barriers are usually addressed later.

questions.question: If an economy is growing at an annual rate of 7% and 4% of that is known to be due to improvements in labour and capital combined, the remaining 3% is usually attributed to
questions.explanation: In growth accounting, the unexplained part of growth after accounting for labour and capital is often attributed to **technical progress or total factor productivity**—captured in D.

questions.question: A major function of middlemen in Nigeria is the distribution of

options.text: commodities to all consumers regardless of income
commodities to consuming centres and the collection of money income to producing centres

questions.explanation: Middlemen (wholesalers, agents, etc.) move goods from **producers to consuming centres** and move payments back to producers. Option B describes this two‑way flow correctly.

questions.question: When a government owns enterprises, a number of advantages arise. Which of the following is NOT one of such advantages?

options.text: Pricing policy may be in the interest of consumers
Government workers may be indifferent towards the public
Income may be more evenly distributed

questions.explanation: Government ownership can allow for more capital, fair pricing, infrastructure development and better income distribution. However, civil‑service complacency—workers being **indifferent** toward the public—is a **disadvantage**, not an advantage, so C is the correct choice.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of localization of industries?

options.text: Development of a pool of skilled labour for the industry

questions.explanation: When many firms cluster in one area, they enjoy external economies (A–D), but congestion (traffic, overcrowding, pollution) is a **disadvantage**, not an advantage. Hence E is the correct answer.

questions.question: The monetary system that requires a double coincidence of wants is known as
questions.explanation: Under **barter**, trade takes place by direct exchange of goods. For a trade to happen, each party must want what the other offers at the same time—"double coincidence of wants". Money systems remove this requirement.

questions.question: The effect of emigration on a country's population, other things remaining equal, is to
questions.explanation: Emigration is the movement of people **out** of a country. With other factors unchanged, this reduces the country's total population size.

questions.question: Money performs a number of functions. One of these functions makes it possible for any person to provide for old age. Because of that function, money is regarded as a
questions.explanation: Being able to **save money now and use it in the future** (e.g. in old age) reflects money’s function as a **store of value**. Other functions do not directly relate to saving.

questions.question: Agriculture plays a dominant role in West African economies because it

options.text: is the focus of the Green Revolution in Nigeria
supplies all the foodstuffs consumed in West Africa
has large plantations of cocoa, groundnut and palm oil
is the main source of revenue in Nigeria
employs more than 50% of the total labour force in West Africa

questions.explanation: In most West African countries, agriculture is the **largest employer of labour**, engaging more than half the workforce. This employment dominance is why agriculture plays such a central role.

questions.question: Which of the following defines Economics most comprehensively?

options.text: Study of human behaviour in the allocation of scarce resources

questions.explanation: A standard modern definition of economics is the **study of how individuals and societies allocate scarce resources among competing uses**. Option C captures this, whereas the others describe only particular activities.

questions.question: Age structure in Nigeria is such that the working age‑group is
questions.explanation: The economically **active population** is generally defined as those aged **15–65 years**, which is option B.

questions.question: NEPA as a public corporation is

options.text: organized in a perfectly competitive market

questions.explanation: NEPA was the **sole provider** of public electricity in Nigeria in 1983; there were no competing suppliers. It is therefore a state **monopoly**, not a competitive firm.

questions.question: Full employment is a situation in which

options.text: all adults who can work are employed
all persons who have attained the age of 15 years and above are employed
all those who are able and eligible to work can find employment

questions.explanation: Economists define full employment as the situation where **everyone willing and able to work at prevailing wages can find a job**. It does not mean literally every adult (A, B, C) is working at all times.

questions.question: When demand is elastic, it means that consumers

options.text: react more than proportionately to price change
are not sensitive to price change
will stop buying when price increases
react less than proportionately to price change

questions.explanation: Elastic demand means the **percentage change in quantity demanded is greater than the percentage change in price**. Consumers are highly responsive; thus they react more than proportionately to price changes.

questions.question: Demand for a factor of production is
questions.explanation: Firms demand inputs (labour, capital, land) **because** they need them to produce goods and services that consumers demand. Factor demand is therefore **derived** from the demand for final goods.

questions.question: Differentiated products are characteristic features of
questions.explanation: In **monopolistic competition**, many firms sell products that are similar but **differentiated** by branding, quality, or features (e.g. different toothpaste brands). Perfect competition requires identical products; monopoly and oligopoly usually focus on market power, not differentiation per se.

questions.question: Nigeria is currently implementing the
questions.explanation: In 1983, Nigeria was in the period of the **Fourth National Development Plan (1981–1985)**, so option C is historically correct for that examination year.
